> in XP, the disc management utility wont allow installing freespace between partitions. > > I want to layout a HHD with four primary partitions, each with different types of encrypted filesystems and 50mb free space between each partition. >
Well, you can do it manually or use some of the "common tools" in a *smart ![:unsure:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/unsure.png)* way. Like, in normal Disk Management: * create a "real" partition the size you want + 50 Mb (NO need to format it) * create a "real" partition the size you want + 50 Mb (NO need to format it) * create a "real" partition the size you want + 50 Mb (NO need to format it) * create a "real" partition the size you want (and format it) * delete partition #1, re-create it 50 Mb smaller (and format it) * delete partition #2, re-create it 50 Mb smaller (and format it) * delete partition #3, re-create it 50 Mb smaller (and format it)
:wink: ![:cheers:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/cheers.gif) Wonko

forumNotes.author: steve6375
forumNotes.content:
WIndows Vista/7 has a DISKPART utility. This allows you to specify an ALIGN parameter which is the number of 512 byte sectors to align the partition start to - e.g. ALIGN=16065 means align the partition at 255\*63 sectors. Now if you use ALIGN=102400 then this should leave a 50MB (ish) gap - but it would depend on the size of your partitions. So to be sure, you would need to make sure your partitions sizes were just over 50MBxX in size - e.g. 20001MB and not 20000MB. You might need to experiment and I have not tried it so I have no idea if this would work as you want...  
Also, for 4K sector drives, make sure that the ALIGN parameter that you use is divisible by 8 or DISKPART may refuse to partition some 4K sector drives.

forumNotes.author: Wonko the Sane
forumNotes.content:
I have NOTHING actually against encryption itself, I have a lot of things to say against ***UN**needed* encryption. (and more generally about needlessly making one's life more complex than it actually is ![:ph34r:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/scared9.gif)) This is because I do **care** for DATA (I actually like each and every little byte and I often carve them bytes one by one. by hand, bit by bit, out of roots and stones ![:w00t:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/w00t.gif)) [http://www.911cd.net...pic=21362\&st=10](http://www.911cd.net/forums//index.php?showtopic=21362&st=10 "External link") and I know from experience that - generally speaking - encryption is particularly used (without actual \*need\*) by the same peeps that normally DO NOT backup their DATA and before or later lose the data and/or more generally lock themselves out of their "secure" whatever. The solutions to the problem: "Hey, I lost my USB stick with all my precious personal data on it, now everyone that found it can have access to all my bank accounts." can be (among - I am sure - many other ones): * encrypt your whole device (and implement an effective, tested, verified and re-verified double - or better triple - backup routine for the whole encrypted device AND follow the rouitne ALWAYS, daily or weekly at the most) * encrypt just the minimal amount of data you need to protect (and implement an effective, tested, verified and re-verified double - or better triple - backup routine for just te little amount of encrypted data AND follow the routine ALWAYS, every time something changes in these data) * DO NOT store \*anything\* you may regret losing on the USB stick * DO NOT lose your USB stick (pay some attention, HECK it contains UNencrypted important data!)
Same approach can be used for a portable (laptop/notebook/smartphone, etc.). For a desktop, as said elsewhere: cleaning lady hacks are not that common, and some mechanical means to prevent physical access to the PC is usally much more effective. Anyway, since you are going anyway to encrypt whole partitions, you will need dd-like or "forensic sound" partition imaging (or whole disk imaging). As a comparison (still about the convenience of it) on a normal system (not encrypted) a dd-like image of a 500 Gb hard disk should take around (talking of "normal" hardware) with something around 60 Gb/hour (through USB 2.0) around 9:30 hours to image your hard disk, or with something like 240 Gb/hour (direct Sata to Sata or e-sata) around 2:15. This you should do daily (or maybe weekly), TWICE (first and second backup copy), and of course burst writing/reading continuously for such extents of time can shorten a bit lifetime of the disks involved. A first run backup of a 500 Gb (let's assume with 2/3 used) may take some (USB 2.0) 8 hours or (direct sata) 2 hours. Each incremental backup session (unless of course you daily delete all contents and replace them with different ones) is normally a question of minutes. About apps to use, there is a rather complete "catalog" here: [http://www.911cd.net...showtopic=16534](http://www.911cd.net/forums//index.php?showtopic=16534 "External link") [http://www.msfn.org/...howtopic=100299](http://www.msfn.org/board/index.php?showtopic=100299 "External link") remember that if you are going into the "encrypted partition" or "encrypted disk" route you will need to chose amone ONLY those capable of dd-like or "sector-by-sector" image. ![:cheers:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/cheers.gif) Wonko
